string-array.name: rules_info
string-array.item: The objective of football is to score more goals than the opposing team by getting the ball into the opponent\'s goalpost using any part of the body except the hands and arms of players.
Each team consists of 11 players on the field, including one goalkeeper. Teams can make substitutions during the match according to the rules.

A standard football match is divided into two halves of 45 minutes each, with a 15-minute halftime break. Extra time and penalty shootouts might occur in knockout competitions if the match ends in a draw.

A player is considered offside if they are nearer to the opponent\'s goal line than both the ball and the second-to-last defender (usually the last outfield player) at the moment when the ball is played to them.

Fouls are committed when a player\'s actions are deemed unfair or dangerous. A free kick is awarded to the opposing team from the spot of the foul. A penalty kick is awarded if a foul occurs inside the penalty area.

Referees can issue yellow cards to caution players for reckless play or persistent fouling. Two yellow cards result in a red card, leading to the player\'s expulsion. A direct red card can be given for serious offenses, resulting in an immediate expulsion.
When the ball goes out of play over the sidelines, the opposing team is awarded a throw-in. The player must use both hands to throw the ball back into play from the spot where it went out.

If the attacking team kicks the ball out of play over the goal line, the defending team is awarded a goal kick. A corner kick is given to the attacking team when the ball crosses the goal line over the end line, last touched by the defending team.

string-array.name: rules_basketball
string-array.item: The objective of basketball is to score points by shooting the ball through the opponent\'s basket, which is a hoop elevated 10 feet above the ground.
Each team consists of five players on the court at a time. Teams can substitute players during stoppages in play.
A standard basketball game consists of four quarters, each lasting 12 minutes in the NBA and international play, or 10 minutes in college and some other leagues.
Points are earned by making field goals (worth two or three points, depending on the distance from the hoop) and free throws (worth one point each), which are awarded after certain fouls.
Players must continuously dribble (bounce) the ball while moving around the court. Double dribbling (starting to dribble again after stopping) is not allowed.
Teams have a limited time (e.g., 24 seconds in the NBA) to attempt a shot. If the shot clock expires before a shot is attempted, the opposing team gains possession.
Personal fouls are committed when players make illegal physical contact with opponents. After a certain number of team fouls in a quarter, the opposing team is awarded free throws.
A player fouled during a shooting attempt is awarded free throws. If a player is fouled in the act of shooting a three-point shot, they can earn three free throws.
The game begins with a jump ball at center court. The referee tosses the ball into the air, and players from each team try to tip it to their teammates.
The ball is considered out of bounds when it crosses the boundary lines. Turnovers occur when the opposing team gains possession due to a steal, offensive foul, or other violation.

string-array.name: rules_tennis
string-array.item: Tennis is played in sets, with each set consisting of games. Players earn points within games using a scoring system of 15, 30, 40, and game. The first player to win four points wins the game.
The server stands behind the baseline and serves the ball diagonally to the opponent\'s service box. If the ball lands in the service box, it\'s a legal serve. Players alternate serving games.

If both players have 40 points in a game, it\'s called "deuce." The player who wins the next point gets "advantage." If they win the following point, they win the game. If the opponent wins, it\'s back to deuce.
To win a set, a player needs to win six games with a difference of at least two games. If the set reaches 6-6, a tiebreaker is played to determine the winner of the set.

In a tiebreaker, players take turns serving for points. The first player to reach seven points with a two-point advantage wins the tiebreaker and the set. A tiebreaker is won by the first to reach 7 points with at least a 2-point lead.
A match is usually played as best-of-three sets for women and best-of-five sets for men in major tournaments. The player who wins the required number of sets wins the match.
In doubles, teams of two players compete on each side. The serving team decides who serves, and each team alternates serving games. The receiving team decides which player receives the serve.

If the ball lands on the lines, it\'s considered "in." If it lands outside the lines, it\'s "out." Players can challenge line calls using a limited number of challenges, which are reviewed using technology.
If the ball hits the net but still lands in the service box, the serve is a "let" and is retaken. During a point, if the ball hits the net and lands in the correct service area, the point continues.

To win the match, a player must win the required number of sets. In a best-of-three-set match, the player who wins two sets wins the match. In a best-of-five-set match, the player who wins three sets wins the match.
